abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for Kerala Rural Water Supply
            and Environmental Sanitation Project and Maharashtra Rural
            Water Supply and Sanitation Project for India were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory; the risk to development
            outcome was negligible to low; bank performance was
            satisfactory; and borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. These two projects increased access to rural
            water supply and sanitation in India. Some lessons learned
            included; improving the quality of rural service delivery to
            increase access to water supply and sanitation improves
            environmental health. Given a supportive institutional
            environment, decentralized, community led water supply and
            sanitation projects can be both effective and less costly at
            providing new rural infrastructure. Government line agencies
            that have traditionally delivered services through a
            centralized, government-led approach face challenges in
            supporting decentralized, community led rural water supply
            and sanitation approaches. The limited availability of
            experienced Non-government Organization (NGOs) capacity to
            facilitate community capacity building can constrain
            adoption of the community-led approach for rural water and
            sanitation service delivery. And there is a role for public
            or private support agencies to provide much-needed expertise
            and technical support to trouble-shoot community-owned water
            schemes. Where this is missing, communities have difficulty
            in planning and managing major maintenance and budgeting for
            the schemes.
